title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act titled "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state. The Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011 imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendments are made to sections 202 and 203, including changes to the paragraph headings and numerical limitations for immigrant visas. The Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011 imposes numerical limitations on visas from any single foreign state under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendments are made to sections 202 and 203, including changes to paragraph headings and numerical limitations for immigrant visas. Additionally, visa numbers are allocated to natives of specific states or areas in a manner that ensures equal proportions based on the total number of visas available. The effective date for these amendments is September 30, 2011, applying to fiscal years thereafter. The Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011 sets numerical limitations on visas by state under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendments include changes to visa allocations for specific states and areas, with an effective date of September 30, 2011. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, percentages of immigrant visas are allotted based on specific criteria. For fiscal years 2013 and 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under specific paragraphs are allotted to natives of states with lower visa numbers in previous years. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, immigrant visas are allocated based on specific percentages for natives of foreign states and dependent areas. Additionally, a special rule is in place to prevent unused visas in those years. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, immigrant visas are allocated based on specific percentages for natives of foreign states and dependent areas. A rule allows visas to be issued without restrictions if the total number available under certain sections is not reached. Rules for chargeability apply in determining the foreign state to which an alien is chargeable. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
